Gor. 8. 3. power, yea and beyond their power they were willing, such bowels of Mercie had they toweards their poore bretheren, that wanted. In the primitiue Church they sold their Lands for the reliefe of the poore. Act 4 34 35 And the Church purposed to send releife to Act. 11. 29. the bretheren which dwelt at Iudea, euen vnrequired thereunto, But now the Fathers of the Primitiue Church are dead, and Mercifull compassion is dead, and gone with them: They relieued the poore to their power, yea, and beyond their power, but now for the most part, among the Countrey people, they that are most power-full are least pitifull; and they that haue most money, haue least mercie. They sold their Lands, and gaue
the money to the poore, but in this sinfull age, some buy Lands, and begger the poore; they willingly releeued their bretheren, though not required therevnto, but (alas) how hardly are men now drawen to distribute to the necissitie of the Saints, yea, euen they that haue great aboundance of wealth, giue what they giue so grudgingly, and nigardly, that the poore finde little comfort: What wringing, oppressing, and beggering of the poore members of Christ is, that in many places which should be relieued, notwithstanding the Word of God condemning all Vnmercifulnesse; and good Lawes, and Statutes enacted to the contrary. If then the Lord had a quarrell with the Children of Israel, and threatned Iudgements against them, because they were vnmercifull, then will he not spare vs now in this Iron age of the world, when most men haue euen shut vp their bowels of mercie.
div.q: Nor knowledge of God in the Land.
div.p:
They were Israelites, how hapned it 1. Ioh. 3. 17. then that they wanted the knowledge of God? The Lord chose them to be his owne Exod. 6. 7.
people, Hee fedde them with Manna in the Exo. 16. 15. Exo. 19 4. Deut. 32. 11. Gen. 17. 9. Deut. 11. 20. Exo. 13. 2. 12. wildernesse, He carried them on Eagles wings out of all daunger. They had the Sacrament of Circumcision. They were commanded to haue the Law of God written vpon their housepostes. Whether it were of their Children, or Beastes, the first borne was conscrated to God. They had the Prophets of God to teach them &c. but though they had neuer so many meanes to know God, and had the word of God among them, yet the Lord heere ceargeth them by his Prophet that there was no knowledge of God in the Land.

This is the ground of all Religion to know God. It were better to bee a beast then a man, and not know God: a beast is in better case then hee, when the beast dyeth, there is an end; but the Soule of man shall liue or die for euer. This is the wel-spring of all doctrine. It is wonderfull that the knowledge of God is not plentifull, seeing there is so much teaching.
div.q: Nor knowledge of God in the Land.
div.p:
This striketh at the root, that there is no knowledge of God in the Land. The wicked indeed haue a naked and
bare knowledge, or lite apprehension of the knowledge of God, and descending into the Heart, but swimming in the Braine like that euill Seruant, That knew his Maisters will, and prepared not him Luk. 12. 47. selfe, neither did according to his will. Yea, the very Diuels know there is a God, Mar. 1. 24. 24. Luk. 4. 41. Luk 8. 28. Act. 19. 15. that there shalbe a resurrection, and a Iudgement.

But there is an other knowledge of God, which carrieth the minde with a full sway to serue God: this is an holy and sanctified knowledge, discending into the Heart: of this knowledge of God, the Prophet heere speaketh: As also Esay prophesying of Christ, sayth; By his Knowledge, shall my righteous Seruant Esa. 53. 11. iustifie many: for hee shall beare their iniquities. Iohn Babtist Was sent to giue knowledge of this Saluation. And S. Iohn Luk. 1. 77. 1. Ioh. 2. 3. sayth. Hereby wee are sure that wee know him, if wee keepe his Commaundementes. Where this knowledge of God is, it bringeth foorth holy obedience to the Lawes of God; not absolute, but a care to doe them: our endeauour must be to please God, and how soeuer wee be other-wayes weake, wee shall finde it as
a meane to purge vs from the corruption of our nature, and to hold vs backe from sinne. They that haue this knowledge, are not vnfruitfull in good Workes, it worketh to their conuersion. If then thou wilt know whether thou haue this sanctified knowledge of God, it shall appeare if thou be fruitefull in good workes, if thou haue not an especiall care to keepe Gods Commandementes, all thy knowledge is sinne before God.

The Israelites had the knowledge of God; but God tels them, they are like the Oxe and Asse. The Oxe knoweth his Esay 1. 3. owner, and the Asse his Maisters Crib; But Israel hath not knowen: my people hath not vnderstood: and the reason was, because they were loaden with iniquitie. vers. 4. And accusing them of sinne by the Prophet Ieremie. They haue not knowne mee Iere. 9. 3. (saith the Lord.) And Dauid saith, They erred in their heartes, because they knew not Psal. 95. 10 his wayes. So in like manner the Prophet Hoseas heere summoning the people of Israel to appeare before the Lord for their sinnes, chargeth them that they wanted the knowledge of God.

They were accused to haue no knowledge of God, because they had not a sanctified knowledge, working in them a care, and conscience to keepe Gods Commandements. And I pray God this sinne be not found among vs. I feare mee it may so. Some want the key of Knowledge, and therefore they cannot open the Chest of God, and deliuer Manna; some are idle, and will not: and where the meane is vsed, it is wonderfull to see how the Diuell seekes to pull it away, and to keepe men in ignoraunce. Vpon the Sabaoth dayes, which are Gods great market dayes for the Soule, when Aarons golden Belles ring, and when God calleth the people to the Welles of the Water of life, It is wonderfull to see how Satan drawes them away, after the pleasures and profites of this World; and laboureth nothing more, then to smother Religion, and the knowledge of GOD: One day of seauen is ordayned of God, as the Lords great schooling day, if the Diuell can steale that day, let him take all. It is the worke of Satan to catch the Word out of our hearts. Math. 13. 19

And seeing that where the knowledge of God is wanting, all vices doe abound: let vs labour to haue an effectuall knowledge of God, lest it be truely sayd of vs, There is no knowledge of God amongst vs. And when wee see or heare the wicked boasting, and prating of God, and of his Mercies and Promises made in his Sonne Christ Iesus, let vs be bould to tell them (as heere the Prophet doth the Children of Israel) that they haue no Knowledge of God. This should teach vs to adde Practise to Knowledge.

To conclude this part, let vs present our selues euery one of vs at the barre of Gods Iudgment seate, as a people indited and arrained vpon these seuerall Inditements, viz. want of Truth, want of Mercy, and the Knowledge of God, and let our owne consciences giue euidence, and sit as Iudges too, and wee shalbe found guilty in all; and therefore no remedy but speedily sue for pardon to the chiefe Iudge Christ Iesus, who is mercifull to all that truely turne to him.

And thus much concerning their
sinnes of omission. It followeth,

p.hi: By Swearing, and Lying, and Killing, and
Stealing, and Whoring, they breake out, and bloud toucheth Blould.

div.p: These words are a proofe of the former accusation, wherein the Prophet proceeds to chrge the children of Israell with sinnes of Commission: and first, with swearing.
Swearing is of two sorts, lawfull and vnlawfull. Againe, a lawfull Oath is of Swearing. two sorts, Promissorium and Assertorium.
By the one, we promise to doe something hereafter; By the other, wee affirme or deny a thing to bee so, or not so: but I will not stand vpon these distinctions.

A lawfull Oath is a solemne and earnest affirmation or negation of a thing lawfull and honest, by the name of God, whereby we desire him who is the onely searcher of the heart, to be a witnesse to the truth, and a puinsher of them that sweare falsely.

A lawfull Oath should haue three companions, Truth, Iudgement and Iere. 4. 2. Righteousnesse▪ this is proued. Thou shalt sweare, the Lord liueth, in Truth, in
Iudgement and in Righteousnesse. As Truth should be the ground of all our speach; so specially, when wee take the God of Truth to witnesse, wee should be carefull to speake nothing but the simple Truth. Wee cannot sweare lawfully, unlesse we sweare truely, our heart and tongue must goe togeather; and wee must be assured we sweare nothing but the truth: And therefore Saint Chrisostome that golden mouthed Father said well. Omnis qui iurat, ad hoc iurat, vt quod verum est loquatur. Whosoeuer sweareth, sweareth to this end, that what he speaketh, be truth. The tongue and minde must sweare togeather. Wee may not equiuocate with the double hearted Papistes, whom GOD hateth, who sweare one thing, and thinke another; who haue one heart for the Prince, another for the Pope, like Iacobs Sonnes, when they talked deceitfully with the Sichemites: Gen. 34. 13. but heart and tongue must ioyne Heb. 6. 16. Gen. 21. 23. 24. Gen. 26 31. Gen. 31. 44. Exod. 22. 8. Numb 5 19 Deut. 21. • . togeather in one truth.

Secondly, he that sweareth lawfully, should sweare in Iudgement. When wee are called before a lawfull Iudge or Magistrate, to testifie a truth, which
may not otherwayes be found out but Iudg. 11 9. 10 2. Sam. 5. 3. 2. Kin. 11. 4. 2. Chro. 15. 14. 2. Chro. 34. 31. by oath; or for any other lawfull cause: Then we should sweare with good discretion and aduisement; not lightly, not rashly, nor doubtfully, but with due consideration, and certaine knowledge of euery particular that wee speake of and that in matters of great importance and necessitie.

A third companion of a lawfull Oath is Righteousnesse. It must be agreeable to right and equitie, and according to Iustice, which giueth both to God and man his due: It must neither be against the loue of God, nor our Neighbour. It must not be an hired Oath, so to sell a mans soule to Sathan for Money; neither for feare, sauour, friendship, nor flatterie; not to doe thy Friend a pleasure, and hurt thy Foe, but in a godly zeale of the righteousnesse of the cause, and with a desire that God may be glorified in the truth.

But there is an other kind of Oath, which is contrary to that trueth which should be in Gods children, and which the Prophet in this place condemneth in the children of Israell: and that is vnlawfull
Swearing, as when men sweare.

list.item: 1 By Creatures.
2 Of Custome.
3 Falsely.

div.p: None should be taken to witnesse a Truth, but onely God the Authour of Truth: God made the Creatures to serue Mans vse; not that wee should Sweare by them, and giue that honour to them, that is due to God, and so make our selues Idolaters.

And the reasons are: First, because God commaundeth it as a part of his worship. Thou shalt feare the Lord thy Deut. 6. 13. God, and serue him, and shalt sweare by his name. Esay the Prophet hauing spoken of the happy estate of the Church, and the miserie of the wicked, sayth, Hee that shall blesse in the earth, shall blesse himselfe Esa 65. 16. Psal. 63. 11. Math. 4. 10. in the true God: and he that sweareth in the earth, shall sweare by the true God.
Secondly, because it is a part of the Inuocation of God. I call God (saith the Rom. 1. 9 2. Cor. 1. 23. Apostle) a record to my soule.
Thirdly, seeing God is called a witnesse to the conscience, wee must onely sweare by him that searcheth and tryeth the heart.

Fourthly, because God in his Word expresly forbids to sweare by Creatures, and complaineth that the Iewes had forsaken him, And swore by them that Iere 5. 7. are no Gods. Our Sauiour Christ forbids to sweare By Heauen, for it is the Throne of God; nor by the Earth, for it is his Footestole▪ Math. 5. 34. neither by Jerusalem for it is the Citie of the great King; neither by thine Head, because thou canst not make one haire white or blacke. And the Apostle Saint Iames saith, Before all things my brethren, Sweare not neither Iam. 5. 12. by Heauen, nor by Earth, nor by any other Oath.

Fiftly, because this kind of Swearing brings downe the Iudgements of God vpon them that vse it. They that sweare Amos 8. 14. by the sinne of Samaria, that is, by Idols, and say, thy God, O Dan liueth, they shall fall, and neuer rise vp againe. And by the Prophet Zophany, The Lord threatneth to cut Zeph. 1. 5. off them that sweare by the Lord, and by Malcham.

This serueth to reproue the Papists, and other prophane Wretches, who sweare by them that are no Gods; or ioyne God with idols; as, by God and the World, God and the Virgin Mary,
God and Fayth, and therefore forsake the Lord. Is the Virgin Saint Mary, a God? Is that patched Idoll the Masse, a God? Is your Fayth, Truth, Fire, Light, Bread, &c. so many Gods? Such Swearers doe forsake the true God of Heauen, and make Creatures their gods. When the Romans sware by the fortune of Caesar, they made Caesar their God. When Nabuchadnezar sware by his Throane and Kingdome, hee made his Iudi. 1. 12. Throane and Kingdome his God. Polycarpus to saue his life, would not sweare by the good lucke of Caesar: and shall we sweare by those that are no gods?

A second kind of vnlawfull swearing is, when men sweare of custome, and in their ordinarie talke garnish their Wordes with gracelesse and needlesse Oathes, whereby they doe dishonour God: This the Lord forbiddeth. Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in Exod. 20. 7. vaine, for the Lord will not hold him guiltlesse that taketh his name in vaine.

And the holy Ghost saith, Accustome not thy mouth ta Swearing, for in it there are Ecclesia. 23. 9, 10, 11. many falles; neither take vp for a custome the naming of the Holy one: for thou shalt not be
vnpunished for such thinges. verse. 10. For as a Seruant which is oft punished, can not be without some scarre: so hee that Sweareth Ecclesi, 27. 14. and nameth God (in vaine) continually, shall not be faultlesse. A man that vseth much Swearing, shall be filled with wickednesse, and the Plague shall not depart from his house. Our Sauiour Christ likewise saith, Let your communication be yea, yea; Math. 5. 27. nay, nay: for whatsoeuer is more then these, commeth of euill. And the Apostle Saint Iames saith, Let your yea, be yea; and your Iam. 5. 12. nay, nay, least you fall into condemnation.

Thus you see, that Swearing vpon custome in our ordinarie talke and communication, is a sinne that God will punish; it leaueth a Brand, and a Marke of Gods vengeance behinde it: the Plagues and Iudgements of God shall cleaue to him, and adide in his house that vseth it: The practise of it (as our Sauiour Christ saith) is of euill, that is, of the Diuell, because hee is the Authour of it: and (as Saint Iames saith) the end of it is damnation, Notwithstanding the corruption of our times are such, that few men make conscience of it, euery Roague taketh the sacred
name of God into his mouth, & maketh it an occupation to begge by: euery Pedler and Petty-chapman, burnisheth his bad Wares, with the glorious name of GOD; and hee is accounted a chapman not worth a Chippe, that will not sweare, to deceiue those that deale with him: neuer was ordinarie and idle Swearing more in request amongst the Iewes, then now among vs Christians.

The last and highest degree of Swearing is Periurie, or swearing falsely. Some make a difference betweene them, as Periurie in that which is to come; and forswearing in falsely affirming, or denying a thing to be so, or not so; neuerthelesse the one is often taken for the other.

This Periurie or false Swearing, is an horrible sinne: the Lord hath expresly forbidden it in his Law. You shall not (saith hee) Sweare by my name falsly neither Leui. 19. 12. shalt thou defile the name of thy God. I am the Lord. The flying Booke of Gods Curses shall enter into the house of him that falsely Sweareth by my name (saith the Lord,) and it shall remaine in the middest of his house,
and shall consume it, with the timber thereof, and the stones thereof. By his Prophet Ieremie Zach. 5. 2. 3. 4. Iere. 5. 2. hee reproueth the Iewes for this sinne. Yea, the Lord Hateth and abhorreth them that gweare falsely. Zach. 8. 17.

And least we should thinke that God would so haue done with them, he saith, They shall not dwell in his Tabernacle, nor Psal. 15. 2. rest in his holy Mountaine. They shalbe excluded out of the holy Cittie; And from the Tree of Life; and they shall haue Apo. 21. 8. their part in the Lake which burneth with fire and brimstone: which is the second death. Apo. 22 15.
How dangerous and damnable a sinne Periurie or false-Swearing is, it may appeare by many Reasons; especially because they sinne,

list.item: 1. Against God.
2. Against them selues.
3. Against their neighbours.

div.p: First, they sinne against God, because when they speake against the Trueth, they speake against God, and take part with the Diuell: and therefore God hateth Pro. 6. 16. 17. 19. them.

Secondly, because they doe not onely turne the Trueth of God into a Lie, but also make God a party in their sinne, &
take the name of the God of Truth, to witnesse a lye.

And thirdly, because they commit high treason against God; for as when an earthly King committeth the great Seale of his Kingdome to the custodie of some one man; If hee to whom the same is committed, should therewith seale Letters of Treason, hee might iustly bee condemned for a Traytour: So, seeing the glorious Name of God is committed to vs, as a Seale, to testifie and confirme the Trueth; as if any man abuse that blessed Seale of the sacred Heb. 6. 16. Name of the King of Heauen, to confirme a Lie withall, hee committeth high Treason against the Maiestie of God.
2. Secondly, Periurie, or False-swearing, is an horrible sinne: because Forsworne wretches do sinne against themselues.

First, in that they doe giue themselues vp to Satan, by their Periurie, they renounce God, and all the sweete Promises conteyned in the Booke of God, whereupon they lay their hand, and bring downe vpon their owne
heads, all the fearefull woes and curses contained in the same Booke; when a false-swearer reacheth out his hand to the Booke, hee giueth it to the Diuell; kissing the Booke, he kisseth the Diuell; when hee bringeth meate or drinke to his mouth with that hand, hee feedeth himselfe with the hand of the Diuell; nay, rather he remaineth a Diuell in carnate, then a man.

Secondly, they doe sinne against themselues, because they make themselues worse then Sathan; For though hee be a lier, and the father of lies, yet wee doe Iohn. 8. 44. not read, that hee durst euer presume to seale his lies with the name of God: But the filthy for-sworne Catife is one degree beyonde the Diuell, for hee is both a lyer, and also dare without reuerence, feare, or trembling, take Gods name into his mouth, to confirme a lye withall; which Sathan neuer durst doe. Iam 2. 19. There is no infirnall Diuell that euer cast himselfe into condemnation for Money; but some Periured persons there are, who readily cast Soule and Body into destruction for a little Pelfe and Drosse of this world; Which
one day shall witnesse against them. Iam. 5. 3.

Thirdly, it is a dangerous and damnable sinne, because for-sworne persons sinne also against their neighbours; whom they hurt or offend by their Periurie. First, if it be in the publique place of Iustice, hee sinneth against the Iudge, in causing him, by his Periurie, to giue vnrighteous sentence; Iudgement is peruerted thereby, and a bad cause passeth for good. Secondly, hee sinneth against the Iurie, in causing them to giue vp a false verdict. Yea, in a word, his Periurie sometimes preuayleth so farre against his Neighbour, that thereby hee carrieth away Lands and Goods wrongfully; and sometimes putteth a true mans Necke into the Halter, and casteth downe his owne soule into Hell.

This sinne is further aggrauated also, by consideration of the matter; If it be in a matter for the glory of God, the saluation of mens Soules, the life of Man, or his state of liuing, or the publique good of the Church or Commonwealth; hee that sweareth falsey in such 2. Sam. 21. 2. Ios. 9. 18. things, his sinne is most horrible. Lastly,
this sinne is increased, when Periured persons doe not onely take Gods name to witnesse a Lye, but also curse themselues, if it be not true which they affirme, whereas in their owne conscience they know it to be a Lie. They will curse themselues to Hell, & protest they will forsake God, if it be not so as they say; they will desire God to confound them, and pray God they may neuer come to Heauen if it be not thus, and thus; with many such like detestable imprecations, as would make a good mans heart quake to heare them Such beastly people doe prouoke God to his face to take vengeance on them: and if the Lord in his Iustice, should take them at their wordes, how miserable were their state?

Let vs then (beloued) vse the Name of God reuerently; and when wee are called to take a lawfull Oath, let vs doe it in Trueth, Iudgement, and Righteousnesse: let vs not accustome our selues to sweare by Creatures, nor to take Gods Name into our mouthes in our ordinarie talke: and be it farre from vs that wee should presume to seale a
Lye with the blessed Name of God, and so sinne against his sacred Maiestie, against our selues, and our soules, and against our neighbours, and make our selues as guilty of swearing, in the highest degree, as euer did the Children of Israel, & so bring Gods fearefull Iudgements vpon our heads.

(And Lying:) Next to Swearing, hee Lying. chargeth them with Lying, and thereby prooueth, that there is no trueth among them: Because Swearing and Lying for the most part are Inmates, and dwell both vnder one roofe, and walke Math. 26. 70. 72. hand in hand, like the Thiefe and the Receiuer: or as the Vsurer and the Broker, (for take a Swearer, and hee is commonly a Lyer:) therefore the Prophet heere placeth them next togeather.
A Lye, is a voluntarie speaking of that which is vntrue, with a purpose to deceiue. S. Augustine maketh mention of eight kinds of Lyes: but others contract them into three sorts.

list.item:
1 A Merry
Lie,
Sport, for Gaine, Spight,
Delight. to Profit. Hurt.
2 An Officious
3 A Malicions

div.p: A Merry or Iesting Lye; when a man of purpose telles a Lie, to delight, and make them sport that heare him. Some goe about to cleare this kind of lying not to be sinne. But our Sauiour Christ saith, That of euerie idle word that men shall speake, they shall giue account Math. 12. 36 at the day of Iudgement. If wee must giue account for euery Idle word, before that great Iudge Iesus Christ; then much more of Idle Lyes. And if the Apostle Saint Paul would not haue vs so much as speake Of any filthinesse, nor foolish talking, nor iesting, which are thinges Ephe. 5, 4. not comely; but rather giuing of thankes. Then why should Christians turne Fooles, to make others sport, or deuise iesting Lyes, to make men laugh, But rather take heede that their speech be alwayes Col. 4. 6. gratious, and powdred with salt, and such as is good to the vse of edifying, and that it may minister (not gaine) but grace vnto the hearers.

The second is an officious Lie, when a man tels a Lie for duties sake, thereby to gaine good to others, by deliuering them from death or danger, or procuring profite to themselues. So the Mid-wiues of Egipt, by a Lie, saued the Children of the Hebrewes aliue, Exod. 1. 19. Rahab by her Lie preserued the Spies Iosh. 5. of Gods people. And Michal by telling a Lie, saued her Husband Dauids 1. Sam. 19. 14. 17. life. Though some Writers, as Origen, and Hierom, and others, seeke shiftes to excuse this kind of Lying in good men, yet they are deceiued; for euery Lie is sinne: yea, though a man would pretend to make a Lie for the glory of God, or the safeguard of a mans life; yet wee may not doe euill, that good Rom. 3. 8. may come of it. And therefore Saint Augustine saith concerning the Midwiues Lie, made for the preseruation of the liues of the young Children of the Ebrewes, That their feare of God, tender care, and carefull compassion, mercifully to spare the Infants, pleased God; but their Lie pleased not God. And if (as the same Father saith) it bee not lawfull to Lie, though it
could be to the prayse of God; much lesse then for the sauing of a mans life. Iob therefore reprooued a Lie in his Friendes, though it tended to defende the Lord: Will you speake Wickedly (saith Iob. 13. 7. hee) for Gods defence, and talke deceitfully for his cause? To say then that some Lies are good, is as much to say, some Sinnes are good. Gods Law is Truth, & whatsoeuer is contrarie to the Truth, is contrarie to Gods Law: But euerie Lie is contrarie to the Trueth, therefore euery Lie is contrarie to Gods Law. True it is that one sinne is worse then another; so is one Lie worse then another: but euery Lie is sinne. God and Satan are two contraries; so are Trueth and Lying: Truth is from God, and Lying is from the Diuell. Though God can doe all things; yet hee cannot Lie, because it is contrary to his nature: but Tit. 1. 2. when Satan lyeth, hee speaketh of his Heb 6. 8. Ioh 8. 44. owne.
Let no man then iustifie that which God condemneth; but let all those that loue the GOD of Truth, and hate the Diuell, loue Truth, and loath all manner of Lies.

Againe, as some goe about to make good this kind of Lying, which tendes to the preseruation of life, and to gaine good to others: So there is some amongst vs, that say, it is no sinne to Lie for aduantage, thereby to bring profite to themselues, or keepe togeather that which they haue, alleadging the example of Iacob, who by his Mothers Gen. 27. 19. counsell, made a lye to his Father Izhak, thereby to gaine his Blessing. They might as well say that Adulterie and Murther are no sinnes, because Dauid a man after GODS owne heart, committed them both. Wee must liue by Lawes, not by Examples: The falles of Gods Children are mentioned in the Booke of life, for our comfort and instruction; not for our Imitation: Wee are to follow the Saintes no farther, then they follow the Lord. So also Gehazei made a Lie to Naaman the Syrian, thereby to make a gaine to 2. King. 5. 22. 27. himselfe: but it proued a madde kinde of gaine; for hee gained the Leprosie to himselfe and his posteritie. Such there bee many now adayes, who make no conscience to Lie for aduantage; yea,
if they haue a Child or a Seruant that can Lie, to gaine them a Groat, oh, that is a Child alone, that is a Seruant alone: But they doe little consider that such gaine gotten by Lying, brings a curse vpon all that a man hath.

Ananias and Saphira Lied for aduantage, thereby purposing to saue to Act. 5. 3. 8. themselues halfe the price of their land; but they payde deare for their Lying, they made but a sory match of it. But though Ananias and Saphira were manie hundred yeares agoe stricken dead by Gods iust Iudgement, for this kind of Lying, yet there is still some of their brood amongst vs. Let a Poore man make his moane to the Rich for maintenance or reliefe, their answere (for the most part) is readier then their Almes, GOD helpe thee, I haue it not for thee; and so looking vp their Charitie, they make no conscience to belie the Lord, who hath giuen them enough both for themselues, and the Poore.

Were it not a iust thing with God, to part such Peasants and their Pelfe, by some sodaine Iudgement or other.
Take heed then, learne not thy tongue to Lie for aduantage, though thereby thou couldest gaine, or saue a Kingdome to thy selfe. Euery Lie is sinne, and the reward of sinne is death. And, Rom. 6. 23. Mat. 16. 26. What shall it profit a man to winne all the World, and to loose his owne Soule.

The third and worst kind of Lying, is a malicious or pernitious Lie, proceeding from a corrupt minde, and tending to the hurt of others. So Potiphar Gen. 39. 14. 15. 17. 18. his wife be-lyed Ioseph. Such a Lie the false-witnesses testified against Naboth, 1. Kin. 21. 13. which cost him his Land, and his Life too. So the two Elders be-lied Susanna, Dan. 13. 36. 37. 38. and set her hard for her life. Such a Lie also Haman told against Mordocai and Ester. 3. 8. the Iewes. And the Pharisies against Christ. No man was euer so impudent, Math 9. 3. Mat 12, 24. as to goe about to excuse, much lesse to defende this kinde of Lying. Whether then it bee a merry, an officious, or malicious Lie, though you turne the fayrest side of it outward, and make the best of it, yet if it be a Lie, it is sinne, and the worke of Satan, and that for these reasons.

First, because God forbids all kindes
of Lies without distinction. Thou shalt Leui. 19 16. not (saith the Lord) walke about with Tales among thy people, &c. I am the Lord. Ʋse Eccles. 7. 13. not to make any manner of Lie, for the custome thereof is not good. Dauid saith, That God shall destroy them that speake Lies. Psal. 5. 6. Our Sauiour Christ sayth (without making difference of Lyes) That Satan Ioh. 8. 44. is a Lyer, and the Father thereof. The Apostle Paul would haue vs cast off Lying, And speake trueth euery man to his Neighbours: for wee are members one of Col. 3. 9. another. And againe, Lie not one to another, seeing that you haue put off the Old man with his Workes: Who will not make conscience of Murther, because God forbids it? And seeing God commaundeth to speake Truth, and forbids all Lying, thou shouldest not Lie, if thou couldest gaine an house-full of Gold by it; because God forbids it.

Secondly, because God and good men hate and abhorre it, and therefore it is twice repeated among those sinnes which God hateth. And againe, The Lying lippes are abhomination to the Lord. Prou. 6. 16. 19. Prou 12. 22. And therefore the holy Ghost preferreth a Thiefe, before a Lyer: a Thiefe
is better then a man that is accustomed to lye: But they both shall haue destruction Pro. 20. 24. to heritage.

And as God abhorreth all Lying, so good men also hate it. A righteous man (saith Salomon) hateth Lying wordes: Pro. 13. 5. Eccle. 25. 2. but the wicked causeth slaunder, and shame. Dauid would not suffer a Lier to dwell in his House, nor tarrie in his sight. There shall no Deceitfull person (saith hee) dwell within mine House; Hee that telleth Psal. 101. 7. Lies shall not remaine in my sight. And therefore as Salomon prayed against Lying, so let all Gods Children doe the Pro. 30. 8. like.

Thirdly, because Lying hurteth them that vse it, It maketh good men wearie of their companie: It impayreth Iere. 9. 2. 3. a mans credite, because hee that accustometh his tongue to Lie, shall not bee beleeued at all: And therefore Demetrius being asked what a Lyer gayneth by Lying? he answered, That hee shall not be Eccle. 10. 23. 25. beleeued when hee speaketh trueth. A Lie is a wicked shame in a man. And againe, The conditions of Liers are vnhonest, and Eccle 41. 17. their shame is euer with them. verse 25. And therefore Gods Children should
be ashamed of lying. The very care of a mans credite should make him to leaue it.

Fourthly, because it brings temporall Iudgements with it. A False witnesse Pro. 19. 5. (saith Salomon) shall not be vnpunished; and hee that speaketh Lies, shall not escape. The Gibeonites for making a Lie to Iosuah, Ios. 9. 6. 23. were accursed, and made slaues to the Israelites. Gehazi for making a Lie to 2. Kin. 5. 22. Elisha, was punished with Leprosie. Haman for his Lie was hanged. Ananias Ester. 7. 10. Act. 5. 5. 10. and Saphira for their lying, felt the heauie hand of Gods vengeance by sodaine destruction. By the Prophet Micheas the Lord threatneth destruction against the people for their crueltie, and lying. Hee will make them sicke in smiting Micha. 6. 12. 13. them, and desolate. &c. And heere he telleth the children of Israel, that the Lord hath a controuersie with them, And that their Land shall mourne, &c. for lying, and other their sinnes.

Fiftly, if this sinne of Lying bee not repented of in this life, it bringeth at last, eternall destruction both of body and soule; For the Fearefull, and Vnbeleeuing, and the Abhominable, & Murtherers,
and Whore-mongers, and Sorcerers, and Idolaters, Apo. 21. 8. 27. and all Lyers, shall haue their part in the Lake which burneth with Fire and Brimstone; which is the second death. And they shall not enter into the holy and heauenly Ierusalem; but they shall be shut out with Dogges, Enchanters, Whore-mongers, Murtherers, Apo. 22. 15. and Idolaters. God will destroy them that speake Lyes. And the Apostle sayth, Psal. 5. 6. That the Law is not giuen vnto a righteous man, but vnto the lawlesse, and disobedient, 1. Tim. 1. 9. 10. to the vngodly, and the sinner, to the vnholy, and to the prophane, to murtherers of Fathers and mothers, to manslayers, to whoremongers, to buggerers, manstealers, to lyers, to the periured &c. It must needs be a great offence, that causeth a Father to disinherite his Sonne: but such a sinne is liing, that it seperateth them that vse it, from the presence and fauour of the God of Truth, depriueth them of his Kingdome, and maketh them slaues to Satan.
Lastly, because it is a diuelish sinne, both in respect of the beginning, the practise, and end of it.

First, because Satan told the first Lie. And when hee speaketh a Lie, hee speaketh of Gen. 3. 4. Ioh. 8. 44.
his owne.

Secondly, because they that vse it, are of the Diuell: for as Peter was knowne to bee of Galilee, because his speach was as the Galileans; so Liers are knowne to bee of the Diuell, because their speach is alike.

Thirdly, because all Lies shall be punished with the Diuell (as you haue heard) vnlesse they repent: Let all Gods Children then cast away lying, because God forbids it, God and good men hate and abhorre it, it hurteth them that vse it: it brings Iudgements temporall and eternall, and is a diuelish sinne, both in respect of the beginning, practise, and end of it.
(And Killing.) This sheweth more particularly, that there was no mercy Killing. among them; but crueltie, and Killing.
Killing, is also of two sorts: Lawfull, and vnlawfull.

The Magistrate may lawfully Kill, or put to death malefactors; because he beareth not the Sword for naught: Rom. 13. 4. For hee is the Minister of God, to take vengeance on him that doeth euill. The Lord also in his Law approueth, and
commandeth this, Whosoeuer Killeth any Leuit. 20. 9. 10. Leui. 24. 17. Deut. 19. 16. 17. Deut. 22. 22. Psal. 101. 8. person, the Iudge shall slea the Murtherer, through Witnesses. I will (saith Dauid) destroy all the wicked in the land. Where wee may see Dauids authoritie, as hee was a King, hee voweth to God, as a thing acceptable to him, to destroy, and roote out all the Wicked: and therefore hee also charged his sonne Salomon, to put 1. King. 2. 5, 6. 28. 31. 32, Ioab the Murtherer to death: Which may serue as a warrant to Magistrates, (notwithstanding the commandement) to punish Malefactours with death. Besides this, the Commaundement was giuen to man; but the Magistrates 2 Chro. 19. 6. killing, it is not mans killing, it is Gods action, God putteth the Sword into his hand: hee executes not the Iudgements Rom. 13. of man, but of the Lord, and he is Gods minister applying himselfe for the same thing.

They are then greatly deceiued, who thinke it not lawfull to put any man to death, for any cause, but would haue all Mercie, and no Iustice. Let Salomon answeare them in a word. Hee that iustifieth the wicked, and hee that condemneth Pro. 17. 8. the iust, euen they both are abhomination
to the Lord. So Saul, and Achab, by their foolish pittie, prouoked God to 1. Sam. 15. 3. 9 11. 18. 1. Kin. 20. 42. wrath, in sparing of those, whom God would haue put to death.

But there is also an vnlawfull kinde of Killing, which the Prophet in this place, condemneth in the Children of Israel, which is practised specially in three things; Heart. Tongue, & Hand: Psal. 142 2. 3. 4. against all which, Dauid prayeth.

Killing of the Heart, is the fountaine: the Tongue, and Hand, are instruments. The Lord saw that the imaginations of mans Gen. 8. 12. Heart 〈◊〉 euill. And our Sauiour Christ saith, That those things which proceed out of the Mouth, come from the Heart; and Math. 15. 18. 19. they defile the man: For out of the Heart, commeth euill thoughts, murther, adulteries, &c. It is a bloody Heart, that maketh a bloody Man. Saul was a murtherer in Heart and Will, when hee hunted after 1. Sam. 18. 11. 1 Sam. 19. 2. & 20. 31. 33. Dauid, and carried a bloody minde against him. So was Haman a murtherer in Heart, though not in effect. And the Ester 3. 6. Mat 26. 3 4. Mar. 14. 1. Luk. 2. 2. Ioh. 8. 59. Iewes were murtherers, when they went about to kill Christ. When a man carrieth a killing affection, then he is a murtherer, and a right limme of the Diuell.

The bloody-minded Seminaries that are sent ouer into England, and our late Gun-powder traytors, and the rest of that damnable and Popish brood, who haue from time to time, plotted most inhumane and bloody attempts against the Lords annoynted, and the state of this Realme, though the Lord of his meere mercie towardes vs (his Name be therefore euer blessed) hath frustrated their filthy and inhumane attemptes, and brought the Wheele vpon themselues; yet are they accursed Murtherers before God: their blood bee vpon themselues.
Secondly, the Tongue is an instrument wherewith the Heart killeth; and it hath also many weapons to kill withall, especially sixe.

list.item: 1. Counsell.
2. Commaundement.
3. False witnesse.
4. Silence.
5. Slander.
6. Backbyting.

div.p:
St. Iames describeth the properties of a Killing tongue. It is Fire, yea a Iam. 3. 6, 7, 8, 9, 10. world of Wickednesse, it defileth the whole
body, and setteth on fire the course of Nature: and is set on fire of Hell. 7. For the whole nature of Beastes, and of Birdes, and of creeping things, and things of the Sea, is tamed, and hath been tamed of the nature of man. 8. But the Tongue can no man tame, it is an vnruly euill, full of deadly poyson. &c.

Therefore, though the Heathens know not God, yet they know this well enough, and therefore Esope beeing sent by his Maister to the Market to buy the best and worst Meate, hee bought all Tongues; affirming that no flesh was better then a good Tongue, and none worse then a badde Tongue: It is a killing and destroying weapon, and cutteth deceitfully like a sharpe Psal. 52. 2. 4 Rasor. The double Tongue (saith the sonne of Syrach) hath destroyed many that were at peace; it hath disquieted many, and driuen Eccles. 28. 13. to 22. them from nation to nation; strong Cities hath it broken downe, and ouerthrowne the houses of great men. The stroke of the Rodde maketh markes in the flesh; but the stroke of the Tongue breaketh the bones. 17. The tongue hath sinne more then the Sword. 28. The death thereof is an euill death, Hell were better then such one. A killing Tongue is
compared to a Serpents tongue. It is compared to an Arrow, and a sharpe Psal. 140. 3. Sword: Nay, it is worse then any sharpe Iere. 9. 8. Iob. 5. 15. Psal 64. 3. Psal. 59. 7. Psal. 120. 4. Sword, or Arrow; for the Sword, and Arrow, onely wound, or kill the Body; but a badde Tongue also hurteth or killeth a mans estimation and good name. A man may beare off, or flie from the stroke of the Sword, or shot of the Arrow; but there is no way to escape a klling Tongue. The woundes which the Sword, or Arrow giueth, may bee healed; but no Salue can cure the wounds of a badde Tongue. The Sword or Arrow kill, or hurt none, but those that are at hand, or not farre off: but a murthering Tongue, woundeth and killeth those often, that are many miles distant.

Seeing then that the Tongue is such a perilous weapon, that there is no medling with it, let vs onely pray against it, as Dauid did. Heare my voyce (O God) in my prayer, preserue my life from Psa. 64. 1. 2. 3 Iob. 5. 21. feare of the enemie. Hide mee from the conspiracie of the Wicked, and from the rage of the workers of Iniquitie, which haue what their Tongue like a Sword, and shot foorth
their Arrowes bitter words.

Thirdly, the Hand is also an instrument wherewith the Heart killeth, sometimes by the ministerie of an other. So Dauid killed Ʋrias. So Ahab 2. Sam 11. 6. 14 15. 1. Kin. 21. 7. 10. and Iezabel killed Naboth. So Herod killed all the male Children that were in Beth-lem, and in all the coastes thereof; which is to bee considered of such bad men, as when they cause others to commit Murther, thinke themselues innocent: but let all such know, that they are Murtherers, though they vse others as their instruments.

Sometimes also the Hand killeth by withholding or taking away things nenessarie from them that haue need: For hee that withholdeth or taketh away the meanes whereby life is preserued, hee is a Murtherer.

And therefore the Lord in the Law, saith, Thou shalt not oppresse an Hired seruant, that is needy and poore, &c. But thou Math. 2. 16. Deut. 24. 14. 15. shalt giue him his Hire for his day, neither shall the Sunne goe downe vpon it, for hee is poore, and therewith sustayneth his life, least hee cry against thee vnto the Lord, &c. And hence it is, that the Lord by his
Prophet Esay chargeth the vnmercifull Esay 1. 15. and oppressing Iewes, that their Hands are full of Blood. And Iesus the sonne of Syrach saith, Who so bringeth an Offering of Eccles. 34, 21. 22. 23. the goods of the Poore, doth as one that sacrificeth the Sonne before the Fathers eyes. 21. The Bread of the needfull, is the life of the Poore; hee that defrawdeth him thereof, is a Murtherer. 22. Hee that taketh away his Neighbours Liuing slayeth him: and hee that defrawdeth the Labourer of his Hire, is a Bloodshedder. Thus the greedie cutthroates of the World kill their Breathren, by suffering poore Soules to stand crying at their doores, without comfort; of whom St. Augustine saith, Si non pauisti, occidisti.

Others, by their immoderate inhauncing of the price of thinges, racking Rentes, depopulating of Townes, and turning out the Poore to begge, and taking away the meanes of their maintenaunce, become guiltie of their blood.

Sometimes also the Hand Killeth by actuall Murther, committed vpon the body of another. So Kain killed his Gen. 4 8. 2. Sam. 3. 27 2. Sam. 20. 10. brother Habel. So Ioab killed Abner, and
Amasa.

And lastly, when a man layeth violent hands on himselfe; So Saul and his Armour bearer fell vpon their Swords, and 1. Sam. 31. 4. 5. 2. Sam. 17, 23. Mat. 27. 5. killed themselues. Thus also Ahitophel, and Iudas, hanged themselues.

Hauing thus shewed you how many wayes this sinne may bee committed; now it remaineth to shew you, that this Capitall sinne (Killing) is most horrible and abhominable, and that for these speciall reasons:

First, Because God forbids it in his Law. Yea, the very Infidels abhorre it. If there Exod. 20. 13 Deut. 5. 17. Math. 5. 21. Rom. 13. 9. Act. 28 4. were no more but this, it were enough to make any Christian tremble to conceaue so much as an intent to commit it.

Secondly, because it is a crying sinne: when Kain had killed his brother Habel, God told him, That the voyce of his brothers Blood, cryed vnto him from the Earth. Gen. 4. 10. Neuer was droppe of Innocent blood shedde, but it cryed for vengeance: and therefore Iob sayth, That the Earth can Iob. 16. 18. not couer Blood.
Thirdly, because it is an accursed Deut. 21 9. sinne.
First, it bringeth the Curse of God Gen. 4. 8. 11. vpon the Murtherer, and maketh him carry a guiltie Conscience: as wee see in Kain.
Secondly, it bringes a Curse vpon a 2. Sam. 3. 29 mans posteritie.
Thirdly, the Magistrate is accursed, 2. Sam. 12. 10 that leaueth it vnpunished.
Fourthly, it defileth the Earth, and 1. Kin. 2. 31. 33. Ier. 48. 10. Iud. 20. 13. 44. Gen. 4. 12. Ioh. 8. 44. 1. Ioh. 3. 12. maketh it accursed.

Fiftly, because it is also a diuelish sinne. It proceedes from the Diuell, Who was a Murtherer from the beginning. Therefore when thou seest a Murtherer, thou seest the very Image and Picture of the Diuell. Kain the Murtherer, was of the Diuell; his Murther, was the worke of the Diuell. After that 1. Sam. 16. 14. the Spirit of the Lord was departed from Saul, and an euill Spirit sent of the Lord vexed him. Saul thencefoorth hunted Dauid for his life, to Kill him. The two possessed with Diuels, were so fierce, that no man might goe by that way, (such a delight they had to Kill men.) Satan no sooner entred into Iudas, but Math. 8. 28. Luk. 22. 3. 4. Ioh. 13. 2. presently he sought Christes blood, to haue him put to death. Therefore bloodie
Papists, who practise to kill & poyson Kinges and Princes, are of the Diuell, and ledde by the spirit of the Diuell: Those Popish Frogges whom Anti-christ sendeth to stirre vp hurly-burlyes among Princes▪ and hide themselues, croaking in corners, to doe mischiefe, came out of the mouth of the Apo. 16. 13. 14. Dragon, the Beast, and false Prophet. See then with what spirit the Seminaries, and other bloody minded Papistes are ledde, who practise nothing but Murthering and Poysoning of Christian Princes; their worke is of the Diuell, and they are guided by his spirit. The Spirit of God is otherwise affected; for when Dauid might haue slaine Saul, at two seuerall times hee would not, but 1. Sam. 24. 5. 6 7. 1. Sam. 26. 8. 11. sayd, The Lord keepe mee from doing that thing to my Maister▪ the Lords Annoynted; yea, hee was touched in heart, because hee had cut off the Lappe which was on Sauls Carment. If Dauids heart smote him, for touching the Kings Garment, What shall become of them that would pierce the Kinges Heart? Neuer did any Heretiques maintaine Treason, & Murthering of Princes but the Papists.
Touch not mine Annoynted, (said God:) Psal, 105. 15. Nay Kill Gods Annoynted, say the Papists. If the Pope were Peters successor, 1. Pet. 2. 13. 17. then would hee teach the people to honour Kinges and Princes, and submit themselues to them, as Peter did. But the Pope sendes out his blood sucking Shauelinges to kill Christian Princes; and therfore he is not Peters successour, but hee is of his Father the Diuell, who was a Murtherer from the beginning.

Fiftly, because God hath a Controuersie with the people for this sinne, and will haue account of all the innocent blood that is shedde; and will bee auenged on them that shedde it. I will (saith the Lord) require your blood wherein Gen. 9. 5 6. your liues are: at the handes of euery Beast will I require it, and at the hand of man, euen at the hand of mans brother will I require the life of man. Who so sheddeth mans blood, by man shall his blood be shedde; for in the image of God, hath he made man. And the Lord God in his Law commaundeth, That hee that killeth any man, shall be Leui. 24. 17. Num. 35. 16 17 18. 19 20. put to death. And also hee forbids that any shall sell the blood of the Murdered. You shall not (saith hee) take any
recompence for the life of the Murtherer, Num. 35. 31 which is worthy to die, but hee shall bee put to death. And our Sauiour Christ said to Peter, That all which take the Sword, shall Mat. 26. 52. perish with the Sword. Ioab slue Abner and Amasa, Absolon, and others; and 2. Sam 3. 27 2. Sam. 20. 9. 10. 2. Kin. 2 32. 33. 1. Kin. 18. 4. 1. Kin. 21. 8, 10, 17. at last, by Gods iust iudgement himselfe was slaine. Iesabel caused the Prophets of God to be slaine, and procured Naboths death: but at last, she was cast out at a Window, her blood was sprinkled vpon the Wall, and vpon the Horses; and shee was troden vnder foote, and the Dogges eate her flesh, so that no 2. Kin. 9. 33, 35, 36. more was found of her but the Skull, and the Feete, and the Palmes of her Hands. Herod Agrippa, hauing persecuted the Christians, killed Iames the Act. 12. 2, 3, 23. brother of Iohn with the Sword, and put Peter in Prison &c. at last by Gods iust iudgement, Hee was eaten of Wormes, and gaue vp the Ghost. And though the Murtherer sometimes die in his Bed, yet, as Goliath was slaine with his owne sword; 1. sam. 17. 51 so the Murtherers owne Conscience shall wound him, and continually torment him. Such a curse fell vpon Kain, his Conscience after hee had killed his
brother Habel, That hee thought euery one Gen. 4. 14. that saw him, would sley him. It is written of Herod Antipas, that after he had beheaded John Baptist, hee carried such an accusing Mat. 14. 10. Conscience, that hee thought euery Bush was Iohn Baptist. Nero also, that bloody persecutour of Christians, is said to haue had such a guiltie Conscience, that he thought that all the Christians which hee had put to death, followed him: and at last, when he had slaine his deare friend Symmachus, his accusing Conscience did so torment him, that sitting at meat, he thought the eyes of Symmachus looked on him in euery Dish; and so fell vpon his owne Sword, and killed himselfe. Thus you see how God will haue account of Innocent blood-shed, and wil be auenged on them that shed it.

And sixtly, vnlesse such bloody wretches doe repent truely while this time of grace lastes, they shall goe vnder Gods heauy wrath for euer. Our Sauiour Christ saith, Whosoeuer killeth, shall be Mat. 5. 21. culpable of iudgement. The Apostle Paul pronounceth of them. That they shall not Gal. 5. 21. inherite the Kingdome of heauen. They shall
haue their part in the Lake that burneth Gal. 5. 21. with Fire and Brimstone. And they shall be shut out of Gods Kingdome, with Dogges, Apo. 21. 8. Enchanters, Whoremongers, &c. Apo. 22. 15.
Lastly, this sinne is aggrauated by consideration of the person Killed, or Murthered.

If it be a great sinne to Kill any Christian; much more a Saint, or Child of God, who is deare to him; in whom God delighteth, and in whom the image of God doth chiefly shine; and in whom Christ Iesus is persecuted: Act. 9. 4. because who so killeth such a one, doth (as it were) sheath his Sword in the heart of Christ. For wee are members of Ephe. 5. 30. his body, of his flesh, and of his bones. If hee which killed Kain, a wicked man, Gen. 4. 15. should be punished seauen fould, What is to be said of him, who killeth a godly man? Yea, What of those that haue killed the Saints, and Martirs of Iesus Christ? It is vnpossible but that their blood should cry aloud for vengeance. How long Lord, holy, and true; dost thou not Apo. 6. 9. 10. iudge and auenge our blood on them that dwell on the Earth. Let the Strumpet of Rome looke to this, Who hath been many
yeeres drunken with the blood of the Saintes, Apo. 17. 6. and with the blood of the Martyrs of Iesus. In the tenne Persecutions, it was counted good sport in the Romaine Empire to kill, and murther Christians in great multitudes, when they were gathered togeather in Prayers. In that bloody Nero his time, they vsed to make Bonefiers with the bones of Christians, whom they had Murthered: In which bloody Persecution, the poore Church, and Children of God, remayned from the Ascention of Christ, almost the space of foure Hundred yeares, till that blessed Emperour Constantine the great, sonne of Helena an English woman, established the Church of Christ: At which time, that good Bishop Eusebius, writer of the Ecclesiasticall Historie, obtained Licence, and Letters of authoritie, vnder the hand & seale of the said Emperour, to make search throughout all the Monarchie of Rome, of the number of all those that had suffered in that time of Persecution, for the Fayth and testimonie of Iesus Christ; and it was found (as Hierom writing to Chromatius and Heliodorus, doth witnesse) that there
had been put to death in that time, for euery day in the Kalender, fiue thousand Martirs, except onely the first of Ianuarie; which day was festiually kept throughout their Romaine Empire, for the choosing of their Consuls.

What need I speake of the aboundance of the blood of the blessed Martirs, which was shed in this land, by that drunken Whore of Rome, while that Church vsurped supremacie in this Realme, during the reigne of Queene Mary: and yet doth that vnsatiable monster still thirst after more blood.

To end this part, let al Gods children take heed of Killing with heart, tongue, or hand: Let the life of man be precious 1. Sam 26. 21. Pro. 24. 11. in our eyes. And be it farre from vs, that wee should defile our hands with the blood of any of Gods children, least so we should be guiltie of this sinne, as were the people of the Iewes, who killed Mat 23. 37. the Prophets, & stoned them which were sent to them, and with whom the Lord hath a controuersie for this, and other their sinnes.

(And Stealing) All manner of vniust Stealing. coueting, getting, or with-holding of
that (which by the right of proprietie) is not a mans owne, is theft. The Prophet doth not heere meane onely such poore and pettie Theeues, as are commonly arraigned at euery Sessions, but such as steale by Oppression, Extortion, Vsurie, and the like. There be few that can truly say with Samuel, Behold heere I am, beare record of mee, before the 1. Sam. 12. 3. 4. Lord, and before his Annoynted; Whose Oxe haue I taken? or whose Asse haue I taken? or whom haue I done wrong to? or whom haue I hurt, or of whom haue I receiued any bribe, to blind mine eyes therewith, &c.

Secondly, such Captaines as hauing the conduct or leading of Souldiers, purse vp the Princes pay to their owne vse, or else prodigally spend it, and so pinch the poore Souldiers, and pine them, that they are glad to leape at a crust, and often brought so low and weake, that they are forced to vse vnlawfull meanes to get food, and shortly become vnfit for any seruice.

Thirdly, such as beeing in Office in the Common-wealth, doe more respect Bribes, and their owne priuate gaine, then either Law or Conscience: and if
vnhappily they buy their Offices, then is all Fish that commeth to Nette with them, catch that catch may: then must the poore Countrey people pay for that.

Fourthly, they that get the Goods of Orphants, or poore fatherlesse Children into their handes, and either defraude them of the most part of it; or else driue them to Law, and so cause them to spende as much sometimes, as their Portions come too, before they can recouer that their Parentes left them.

Fiftly, Tradesmen also sometimes, play the Theeues, and sinne againg the Law of God, by oppressing those that deale with them, in so much as Caueat Leuit. 25. 14 emptor, Let the buyer take heed, is frequent in euery mans mouth: But God saith not so, for Christian charitie requireth that the seller looke vnto it, that hee bee not both a Chapman and a Theefe, but that he sell a penny-worth for a Penny, and vse a good Conscience Amos. 8. 6. in his Trade: not to sell counterfaite Wares for good; not to vse false Deut. 25. 13. 14. Waights or Measures, nor to buy by
one Waight or Measure, and sell by an Leuit. 19. 36 Pro. 11. 2 other: which God forbiddeth, and is abhominable to the Lord.

Sixtly, and lastly, (for I will make mention of no more) are all such as beare a gallant shew in the World, and gather other mens Goods into their hands, and when they haue runne as farre as their credite will reach, then turne Banck-rupts vpon the sodaine, bearing the world in hand, that they are not worth a Groate, when as they keepe a great masse of other mens Money secretly to themselues, so that their Creditours are glad to grow to composition, and take that little they can quietly come by: But when euery mans mouth is stopt with a thing of naught, then they shift themselues into some corner of the Country where they are not knowen, and there ruffle it out with other mens Riches, liue in all brauerie, put that foorth to Vsurie, which they haue stolne from others; and so become double and damnable theeues to the Common-wealth: whose Iudgement I leaue to the Lord.

Let vs make vse of this, to our selues;
And let euery one of vs that loue the God of Truth, hate all false-getting of the Goods of this world, and labour in our seuerall places and callings to carry a good conscience, to rest satisfied with meum and tuum, not to desire, purloyne, or with-hold that, which in right is none of our owne: And if any of vs haue fallen this way, let vs with Zacheus make restitution, as Gods law commaundeth; Luk. 19. 8. Exod. 22. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Nehe. 5. 11, 12, 13. Psal. 67. 1. so shall Gods wrath be appezed, the controuersie ended, and God will blesse vs, shew vs the light of his countenance, and be mercifull vnto vs.

(And Whoring.) Whoredome is a filthy and abhominable, but yet a vulgar Whoring. sinne, a number of sinnes attend vpon Math. 5. 28. it. It is taken for all vncleannesse of bodie and minde. I will onely speake of it in act; which hath particular degrees. When it is committed betweene a man and woman both vnmarried, it is called Fornication: If both, or the one party be married, it is called Adulterie: If the parties bee within the Degrees forbidden, Leuit. 18. it is Incest: If forcibly committed it is a Rape. And though one of these be more horrible sinne then another,
yet The wages of the least is death. And therefore S. Augustine saith, Omnia peccata Rom. 6. 23. sunt mortalia, sed omnia peccata non sunt equalia: which may serue to condemne the errour of the Papistes, who hold, that some sinnes in their owne nature are Veniall, and some are Mortall: But the Prophet Ezekiel saith, That the same Ezec. 18. 20. Soule that sinneth, shall die. And Saint Paul telles them, that if it bee a sinne, (mince it as they may) The wages of Rom. 6. 23. it is death, without repentance and Gods mercie. And the same Prophet Ezekiel would haue them know, That if the Wicked will returne from all his sinnes Ezec. 18. 21. 27. that hee hath committed, and doe that which is lawfull and right, hee shall saue his Soule aliue.

So that the least sinne without repentance and Gods mercy, is damnable: and the greatest sinne, if it be truely repented of, and Gods mercy in Christ apprehended by a liuely Fayth, while wee beleeue in this time of Grace, it is pardonable.

This sinne of Whoredome is a filthy and abhominable sinne, hated of God, and all good men, and that for many
reasons.

First, because it taketh away the Heart of a man, as sayth this our Prophet, Whoredome, Wine, and new Wine, Hose. 4, 11. take away the Heart. As Nebuchadnezer had the Heart of a Beast; so when a Whoremonger is that way giuen, hee is carryed headlong with his beastly affections. The Heart is the principall Pro. 23. 26. part of man in Gods seruice. And our Sauiour Christ sayth, Thou shalt loue the Lord thy God with all thy Heart. And the Mat. 22. 32. Apostle would haue vs serue God heartily. If the Heart be away, no seruice Col. 3. 24. can be acceptable to God: But Whoredome taketh away the Heart, therefore Whoremongers can performe no seruice acceptable to God. Wheresoeuer the Body of the Whoremaister is, his Heart is with his Whore; and where euer the Whore bee, her Heart is with her Whoremonger. The Whoremonger is so besotted, and destitute Pro. 6. 32. of vnderstanding, That hee goeth about his businesse like a Foole to the Stockes. Pro 7. 22. It made Dauid such a Foole for the time, that hee went about to couer his sinne, by murthering of his trusty Seruant
Ʋrias.

Secondly, because it is a brutish sin, it maketh a man a beast, though a man in shape, yet a beast in behauiour. Math. 7. 6. Luk. 13. 32. Iere. 5. 8. Prou. 7. 22. Deut. 23. 18. Reu. 21. 8. Whoremongers are cōpared to beasts: to fed horses: To an Oxe led to the slaughter. The price of an whore and a dogge is all one. By a dogge he meaneth as an impudent wretch. Whoremongers are as dogges, and whores as bitches; nay, worse then beastes are they.

Thirdly, because it hath a lawfull remedy. To auoyd fornication (saith the Apostle) let euery man haue his wife, and let euery woman haue her owne husband. They 1. Cor. 7. 2, 9. that cannot abstaine, let them marry: where there is a lawfull remedy, the sinne is more grieuous. God gaue to Adam the fruite of Gen. 2. 16. all the trees in Paradise, but one: hee would not be satisfied with that, but he would needes eate of the fruite of that one tree also which was forbidden, therefore his sinne was the greater. A poore theefe is pittied that stealeth to Prou. 6. 33. satisfie his hunger; but he that stealeth and hath enough of his owne, his sinne is the greater, and more to be punished.
So he that hath a lawfull remedy, and such a remedy as God hath ordained for mans good and comfort, and notwithstanding runneth a whoring, his sin is the more abhominable, and deserueth greater punishment. Such was Dauids sinne, he had many wiues and concubines, and therefore well prouided that way, yet hee tooke another 2. Sam. 12. 4 6, 7, 8, 9, 13. mans wife, and therefore his sinne (by his owne confession) was more horrible.

Fourthly, because Sathan thereby gaineth two soules at once, a theese may steale alone, the drunkard may be drunken alone, the murtherer, swearer, &c. may sinne alone: But the whoremonger killeth two soules at a clap: nay, sometimes Satan gaineth many soules by meanes of one whoremonger or one strumpet. And therefore Ambrose vpon that, Can a man take fire in his bosome, and his cloathes not bee Prou. 6. 27. 28. burnt? Or can a man goe vpon coales, and his feet not bee burnt? And (sayth that Father) how can a strumpet dwell in a towne, and young men not be drawne to whoredome? If the blood of Habel
cryed for vengeance, how much more shall those soules cry for vengeance against the whore-monger which are lost through his default? The whoremonger careth not how many he abuse, nay, the more, the more he reioyceth: and the strumpet careth not how many she leades to the Deuill, the more customers the more merryer, and the more money too, shee openeth her quiuer against Eccelesiasticus 26, 12. euery arrow. But if they knew that all those soules would crie, and pleade vengeance against them, who haue sinned by their meanes, they would turne a new leafe, and returne to the Lord, while time of grace lasteth.

Fiftly, because whoremongers are the Deuils factors, Satan is a tempter, Math. 4. 13. so are they. Honest women may answere them as Christ did Peter, when he went about to intice him to saue himselfe, Get thee behind mee Satan, thou art Mat. 16, 23. an offence vnto mee: So may they answere those members of Satan, that tempt them to whoredome. And as when the Diuell shewed Christ all the Kingdomes of the world, and the glory of them, and sayd Math. 4. 8▪ 9. 10. vnto him, All these will I giue thee, if thou
wilt fall downe and worship mee: but Iesus answered, auoid Satan. So when whoremongers doe offer vnto women, gold, siluer, riches, or great preferments, as the price of their honesty, and soules too, if they wil fall downe to their filthy lust, they may answere the members as Iesus Christ did the head, Auoid Satan, thou tempting Deuill, get thee hence. Whosoeuer laboureth to draw others Act. 13. 8. 10. from God, he is Satans Factor, a child of the Deuill, and an enemie to righteousnesse. When thou hearest or seest such, thou hearest or seest a right member of Satan, let all Gods children take heed of them.

Sixtly, because the whoremonger sinneth against the honour of his owne body, and that many wayes. First, the bodies of Christians are the temples of the 1. Cor. 6. 19. 1. Iohn 2. 17. holy Ghost, and the holy Ghost is that oyntment. As wee will not put sweet oyntment into a stincking boxe: so God will not haue his spirit dwell in a stincking body polluted with whoredome. It banisheth the holy spirit of God, and maketh the body a den for deuils. It is a great offence to plucke
downe the Pallace of a Prince, but a greater to defile the temple of God, for If any man destroy the temple of God, him will God destroy, for the temple of God is holy, 1. Cor. 3. 17. which wee are.

Secondly, because our bodies are the members of Christ, but the whoremonger cuts himselfe off from being a member of Christ, and maketh himselfe a member of an harlot. Shall I take the 1. Cor. 6. 15. members of Christ (sayth Paul) and make them the members of an harlot? God forbid. Wee are vnited to Christ, yea, wee are married to Christ, he is our husband, we are his spouse, we are one with him. Ephe. 5. 30. How fearefull a thing is it then for a man to rend and dismember himselfe from the body of Christ, and make himselfe a member of an harlot?

Thirdly, he sinneth against his owne Prou. 5. 11. Prou. 3 • . 3. Num. 5. 22. 27. body, because he consumeth and wasteth his body. Rotten diseases belong to this sinne. The French pocks, and fearefull diseases accompany it, yea, Ecclus 19. 3. rottennesse and wormes shal haue them to heritage.

Seauenthly, because as the whoremaster sinneth against his owne body,
so also against his owne outward state and goods, for whoredome is the highway to pouerty. Hee that feedeth harlots (saith Salomon) wasteth his substance. The Prou. 29. 3. prodigall sonne hauing spent vp all among harlots and bad women, was in the end brought to such want, that he was glad to play the Swine-heard, and to eate huskes among the Swyne. And therefore Luk. 5. 13. 16. 20. Salomon againe sayth, Because of the whorish woman, a man is brought to a morsell of bread, and a woman will hunt for the precious life of a man. Whores are the deuils Prou. 6. 26. branches to hunt a mans soule to a morsell of bread. Whoredome is compared to fire, because it will wast, consume, and destroy. Whoredome is a fire (sayth Iob) that shall deuoure to destruction, and which will eate out all a mans increase. Iob 31. 12. Nay, it is worse then fire: fire consumeth but earthly things, but the fire of whoredome will consume and burne both soule and body, vnlesse it be quenched with teares of repentance. And therfore the Lord hauing charged them with Adulterie, sayth, Hee will melt them Iere▪ 9. 2, 7. to destruction. When a man or woman is giuen vp to whoredome, then the diuell
runnes away with all, whores haue one part, bawdes another, and the secret curse of God consumeth the rest. Giue an harlot as much as thou wilt, and fee her, and feede her while she will aske, and she shall be neuer the richer, but thou shalt be the poorer; and what though it prosper for a while with some whores, yet in the end the least blast of Gods vengeance will blow all away.

Eightly, because the whoremonger and whore sinne against their own credite, estimation, and good name: for Prou. 6. 33. this sinne robbes a man of his good report, and brands him with a note of infamy. Ecclus. 19. 2. Prou. 5. 9. Their reproach shall neuer be put out. A mans honour, which is his credite, and honesty, is so lost.

Ninthly, because it brings an accusing conscience, if thou knewest but the tenth part of the horrour that Dauid endured and suffered for his Adulterie, thou wouldest not for a thousand worlds commit Adulterie.

Tenthly, because Gods institution concerning Matrimony is so polluted, the couenant betweene God and man made in Baptisme is broken, and so is
the couenant betweene man and wife. They are theeues to God, because by whoredom they steale away from God their soules and bodies, which are not their own but Gods, for Christ bought them with a deere price. The husband 1. Cor. 6. 19. 20. steales from his wife that body which is none of his owne, but his wiues, and the adultresse stealeth from her husband that body which is not her owne, but 1. Cor. 7. 3. 4. her husbands. And further, the whoremonger doth not onely dishoner her body with whom he commits the sin, but also he is a theefe to her husband, in robbing him of his owne flesh, and pulling (as it were) the heart out of his body, in taking her, whom he makes as much account of as his owne heart.

Besides all this, it is an abhominable sinne, because God forbids it, and all the Exo. 20. 14. Ephes. 5. 3. Gen. 39. 12. godly abhorre it. Ioseph chose rather to indanger his life, then to consent to the lust of his filthie mistris. Susanna, rather then she would yeeld to the elders, and Dan. 13. 45. lose her honestie, aduentured her body to the fire, and burned she had beene, had not God deliuered her. But in this sinfull age, many will aduenture their
liues to doe it, and so farre are some from Iosephs affection, in fleeing from bad women, that they hunt after them, till they cast themselues headlong into destruction. Yea, the very Heathens Rom. 2, 14, 15. Gen. 12. 18. 19. Gen. 20. 25. 9. which knew not God, but were led by the light of nature, did hate and abhorre adulterie, as may be seene in Pharao, and Abimelech. When Dionisius the King vnderstood that the young Prince, his sonne, had layen with a mans wife, hee sharpely reprooued him, and asked him, if euer he knew, or heard of any such filthinesse committed by him? The Prince answered no: your father was not a King. No more (saith Dionisius) shall thy sonne be King, vnlesse thou amend thy manners. It is written that Alexander the great, a famous conquerour, but an heathen man, hauing ouercome Darius King of Persia, could in no wise bee perswaded to see the Queene, Darius his wife, who was reported to be wonderfull faire, least he might haue beene tempted to lust after her. Shall not these heathen men, which knew not God, rise vp in iudgement against many Christians, which are so
farre from vsing meanes to auoid this sin, that they follow it with greedines, and vse all meanes to stirre themselues vp to lust.

Lastly, God will not onely afflict temporall punishments vpon whoremongers Num. 25. 9. Iere. 5. 7. 8. 9. 2. Sam. 12. 10. Ecclus. 19. 3 Prou. 31. 3. Prou. 6. 32. Mal. 3. 5. 1. Cor. 3. 17. 1. Cor. 6. 9, 10. Hebr. 13 4. Reu. 21. 8. & 22, 15. in this life, but also (vnlesse they repent) there shalbe no place for them in heauen. The adulterer (saith Salomon) destroyeth his owne soule. The Lord will come neere to them in Iudgement, and will be a swift witnesse against them, (saith the Prophet Malachi.) God will destroy them, saith Paul, they shall not inherit the kingdome of heauen. God will iudge them. They shall haue their portion in the lake that burneth with fire and brimstone, and shall be shut out of Gods kingdome with dogges, murtherers, &c.

See then what an abhominable sinne this is, and what whoremongers gaine by their whoredom. The fairest end of it is shame and repentance, as in Dauid, Magdalen, Rom. 6. 21. and others, which thing the very Heathens well considered, for Demosthenes the Philosopher (as Aulus Gel. recordeth Aul. Gel. noct. Att. lib. 1. ca, 8. out of Phocion) hearing of the fame, or rather infamy, of that notable
strumpet Lais of Corinth, hee went thither secretly, thinking to haue the vse of her body: shee asked him no lesse for a nights worke then tenne thousand Tallents, which is valued to be worth of our coyne a thousand french Crownes. The Philosopher answered her, Non emo tanti poenitere, I buy not repentance so deare. Let euery one labour to keepe his vessell in holynesse and honour; and let them which haue fallen this way be ashamed of their follie 1. Thes. 4. 4. Psal. 78. 18. and filthie former life, and fall to repentance while they haue time, least the Heathens at the day of Iudgement cry vengeance against them. And let euery one of vs be carefull to auoid all occasions that may stirre vs vp to this sinne; and let vs not abuse Gods creatures to lust; Let vs make a couenant with our eyes, as Iob did; and let vs Pro. 7. 15 16. Pro. 23. 31. 33. Rom. 13 13. Iob 31. 1. Pro. 1. 6. 23. 24. Prou. 7. 5. Prou. 2. 16. meditate vpon the word of God, which is a forcible meane against this sinne; it shall keepe vs from the bad woman, which flattereth with her lips, forsaketh the husband of her youth, and breaketh the couenant of her God.
div.q: By swearing, and lying, and killing, and stealing, and whoring, they breake out, and bloud toucheth bloud.
div.p: (They breake out.) The Prophet amplifieth their sinnes by a metaphor of breaking out, alluding to a streame of water, which hauing gotten a little issue, soone becommeth a great flood, and rusheth out with violence.

When men breake out and runne headlong into sinne, commonly they grow impudent and shamelesse in their sinnes, then they sinne before God, Gen. 6. 11. they grow to such impudency, that they care not though God and man see them; Then they carrie their sinnes in their foreheads, they haue whores faces, and Iere. 3. 3. will not be ashamed: Yea, the tryall of their countenance testifieth against them: they declare their sinnes as Sodom, and hide Esay 3. 9. them not.

It is a miserable thing to see bad men breake out, and runne headlong into sinne without shame, as if an impudent strumpet should play the harlot in her husbands sight; and yet men now adaies are growen so shamelesse in sinne, that
(for the most part) they froath out their owne shame, and brag and boast of their bad deeds. Who is ashamed of pride, whoredome, drunckennesse? &c. Doe not blasphemous swearers, extortioners, vsurers, &c. seeke to outface sinne, and neuer blush at it? Many are more ashamed to doe good then euill, and some are more abashed at their base apparell, then their bad liues: yea, though God afflict vs from yeare to yeare with new iudgements, yet still wee rush headlong into sinne, without shame? What yeare of late hath escaped vs, wherein God hath not threatned vs with pestilence, dearth, or vnseasonable weather, and yet still wee breake out into sinne. Let vs then breake off our course of sinne betime, least Gods iudgements breake out against vs, and his decree passe out vppon vs.

Againe, whereas this people did breake out into sinne, as men impudent and shamelesse in their sinnes, it sheweth, that they were farre from true repentance, for where shame of sinne is wanting, there can be no true repentance.
The Lord therefore complained that the Iewes were not ashamed, when they had committed abhomination. What Iere. 8. 12. profit (sayth the Apostle to the Romanes) had ye of those things whereof you Rom. 6. 21. are now ashamed? While Adam and Heuah were in the state of innocency, though they were naked, yet were they not ashamed, but sinne brought shame, and therefore they hid themselues, and sowed Gen. 3. 7. fig-tree leaues together, and made themselues breeches. Magdalen was so ashamed after she saw the filthinesse of her sinne, and what she had deserued, that cōming into the house where Christ was, she stood at his feet behind him, weeping, and began to wash his feet with teares, and wiped them with the haires of her head; all which shewed a shame Luk. 7. 38. and loathing of her sinne. The Prodigall child after he came to true repentance, was 〈…〉 of his bad course of life 〈…〉 to his father,
〈…〉 called his sonne. Luk. 15. 21. And the 〈…〉 was so ashamed
〈…〉 a farre off, 〈…〉 , &c. Luk 18. 13.

They 〈…〉 ashamed of
their sinnes, are farre from repentance, but shame will bee a good meane to bring men to repentance; and therefore the Apostle requireth the Thessalonians 2. Thes. 3. 14. 1. Cor. 5. 9, 10, 11. Math, 18. 17. to excommunicate the obstinate, and haue no company with them, that they may be ashamed. Yea, saith Christ, let him be to thee as a heathen man, and a Publicane, which may serue to reprooue those who haue familiarity with blasphemous swearers, cōmon drunkards, knowen Adulterers, obstinate Papists, or excommunicated persons; such further Satans worke, and hearten bad men in their sinnes, whereas if men would auoid their company, they would grow ashamed of themselues, and be brought to repentance.

Further, where the Prophet sayth, That they breake out into sinne. It appeareth that they were not onely impudent, but also hardned in their sinnes. Of this hardnesse of heart the Apostle warneth the Hebrewes; Take heed, least Heb. 3. 12. there be in any of you an euill heart.

It is a fearefull thing to be brought to hardnesse of heart. Hee that hardeneth his heart (sayth Salomon) shall fall into Pro. 28. 14.
euill. So Zedekia hardened his necke, and made his heart obstinate, that hee might not returne to the Lord God of Israel. 2. Chro. 36. 13.

He that breaketh out into sinne with an hardned heart, seeth not in what a desperate state hee stands. As when a sick man feeleth not that he is sicke, or a man wounded to death, will not bee perswaded that he is hurt: so desperate is hee and vncureable, that breakes out into sinne with an hardned heart, and hath no feeling of his sinne: for when the heart is once growne hard, then the working of Gods spirit is taken away.

Againe, his state is desperate, that breakes out into sinne with an hardned heart, because nothing can stay him: As it is an hard thing to stop a violent streame of water, forcibly breaking out; so difficult a thing is it, to stay him that with an hardned heart rusheth out headlong into sinne. When Dauids heart was hardned a while in sinne, and himselfe brake out into a bad course of life, (though God crossed him many 2. Sam. 11. waies to haue stayed him) yet on hee goes, nothing would worke vppon
him, till he had added murther to his adulterie, and so blood touched blood. When Balaam had once taken a bad way, nothing could hinder him (though Num. 22. God vsed wonderfull meanes) still forward goeth he with his wickednes. And when Iudas his heart was hardned against Mat. 26. 48. Mar. 14. 11. Christ, there was no stay with him, he waked when others slept, because he would effect his intented treason. It is much adoe (saith one) to stay him that rideth on the Deuill; so headlong runne they that breake out into sinne with hardned hearts.

Let euery one take heed how hee thus breakes out into sinne: the ground that is hard, will not suffer the purest seed to grow in it; neither will an hard heart suffer the celestiall seede of the word to take roote in it, nor the spirit of God to worke vpon it. And therefore when thou commest to heare the word of God, which is the power of God to saluation to euery one that beleeueth, bring Rom. 1. 16. with thee a melting heart, for if thine heart be hardned, the word (which is the ordinary meanes of thy conuersion and saluation) will not worke vpon
thee, nay, thou hearest it to thy condemnation. And when thou feelest any heate, or sparke of Gods spirit, then presently blow at it, and vse all good meanes, that thine adamant heart may be pearced with the word, and operation of the spirit.

(They breake out) Lastly, where the Prophet chargeth this people that they breake out by swearing, lying, killing, stealing, whoring, &c. I doe further note, that there are degrees in sinne, and when a man is once entred into a bad course, hee euer breakes out to Iere. 9. 3. worse and worse, vnlesse God stay him. As a spring sends out but a small streame at first, but the further it runneth, the more small brookes ioyne with it, till it become a great Riuer: So the longer a bad man runneth on in sinne, the more sinnes he heapes vp together, and therefore Salomon sayth, The beginning of strife is as one that openeth the Prou. 17 14. Ecclus 3. 2 • . Psal. 1. 1. waters, &c. Dauid makes mention of three steps of sinne, walking, standing, and sitting downe in sinne. When a man is resolued to sit him downe, and rest in sinne, then he maketh but a iest
of Gods threats. The wicked and Atheists count three sorts of people happy, The proud (say they) are blessed, they that worke wickednesse, are set vp, and they Mal. 3. 15. that tempt God, yea, they are deliuered. See how Kain brake out into sinne, and blood touched blood.

First, Hee was angrie at his brothers sacrifice, then hee hated him, then hee killed him, then hee was so blockish, that hee thought God sawe not his sinne, and Gen. 4. 5, 8. therefore made a lye to God, and lastly, he despaired of Gods mercie. Sinne will grow to a streame, if it be not resisted in time. The floods of wickednesse (sayd Dauid) made mee afrayd. Sinne is like Psal. 18. 4. the spaune of a Fish, it will increase to a multitude.
