As one deepe calleth another, Psal. 42. 9. so one sinne brings on another: and as one disease of the body (if it be not in time cured) brings in a many moe, so doth one disease of the soule: and as hee that hath the dropsie, when he hath drunke is the dryer; so when a man hath entred into a bad course of life, for the most part, hee breakes out with more violence, into sinne.

Dauid was a man beloued of God, hee rose euery night at mid-night to Psal. 119. 62. Psal. 55. 18. praier, but how did he breake out from one sinne to other, because he did not resist the first motions of sinne? First he saw Bethsheba washing her selfe, then hee lusted after her, then hee lay with 2. Sam. 11. 2. 4. her, then hee vsed many bad and sinfull meanes whereby to hide his sinne; and lastly, hee caused Ʋrias to be slaine.

The like wee see in Peter a notable Apostle of Christ Iesus, ready to answere at euery turne; First, at the demaund Math. 26. 70. 72. 74. of the silly wench hee denyed his Master Christ; then hee sware hee knew him not; and lastly, hee cursed himselfe, and sware, he knew not the man.
If God had giuen Kain grace to haue resisted sinne at first, he had not growen to that extremity of sinne.
If Dauid had withstood Sathans temptations, when hee saw Bethsheba washing her, he had neuer broken out to that height of sinne, as he did.

And if Peter had stopt sinne at first when it brake out by simple denyall, he had neuer runne headlong to swearing
and cursing.

If such excellent men as Dauid and Peter went so farre, because they resisted not sinne at first, let all Gods children take heed of Sathans subtilty, and withstand the first motions of sinne, and cut it downe while it is sprouting; for if sinne and Satan get the least entertainment, they will till thee on from bad to worse, till there bee no remedy: Mat. 12. 45. and as one deuill brought in seauen, so one sinne will bring in many.

As he that runneth downe a hill can hardly stay himselfe till he come to the bottome; so hee that beginneth a bad course of life, can hardly stay his affections till hee come to the extreamity of sinne.

It is a fearefull thing to goe on from sinne to sinne, so as bloud touch bloud, and one sinne follow in the neck of another, and therefore wee should abstaine from all appearance of euill. And as 1. Thes. 5. 22. wee are carefull not onely to auoyd the pestilence, but also not to come neere the clothes that are infected with it; so let vs not onely labour to smother wicked motions at first, but also
euen hate the very garment spotted with the Iudg, 23. flesh.
Dauid and Peter being admonished, straight wayes repented: so let vs destroy sinne while it is young, least if it take head, it destroy vs.

And as he was blessed that tooke the children of the Babilonians, and dashed Psal. 137. 9. them against the stones, so shalt thou be blessed, if thou takest thy sinnes while they are yong, and killest them, as it were in the cradle, and destroyest them. But woe to thee, if thou suffer thy sinnes to domineere, to growe to an head, and to breake out, like a violent streame, till one blood-giltines touch another, and then is thy state more dangerous, because greeuous sinnes must haue great repentance.

(And blood toucheth blood.) Blood is Esay 1. 15. Deut. 17. 8. not onely taken in the Scriptures for murther, but also for great and grosse sinnes. In all ages of the world sinne hath abounded, I need not to set down particulers thereof, let all the bookes of the Bible testifie the trueth of this proposition. And let vs looke to our selues, in this yron age of the world,
and see if all sorts of people doe not also now breake out into sinne? Hath not all flesh now corrupted his way vpon earth, as in Noah his time? Is it not with vs, as in Dauids time? Do not Psal. 12. 2. most men flatter with their lippes, and dissemble in their double hearts. May we not truely say, That deceipt and guile goe not Psal. 55, 11. out of our streetes. Are not Ioabs daggers, and Iudas his kisses commonly put in practise among vs? and therefore let vs consider how the Prophet in the next verse, denounceth Gods iudgements against them, and tells them, that the land shall mourne.

p.q: Therefore shall the Land mourne, and Verse 3. euery one that dwelleth therein shall bee cut off, with the beastes of the field, and with the foules of the heauen, and also the fishes of the Sea shall be taken away.

div.p: THis verse containeth the fourth part of my former diuision, namely, the temporall iudgements of God against this people for their sinnes.

(Therefore (saith he) shall the Land
mourne, &c. As the land is sayd to reioyce, when God blessed it with plenty; Esay 30. 23. Ioel 2. 21. Psal. 65. 14. and the vallies are sayd to laugh and sing, when they stand thick with corne, so heere it is sayd, The Land shall mourne, when God shall curse it with barrennesse, for mans sinne; and so also the Prophet Esay sayth, The earth lamenteth, and fadeth away. A fruitefull Esay 22. 4. Land (saith Dauid) hee maketh barren for Iere. 12. 4. Lam. 1. 4. Psal. 107. 34. the wickednesse of them that dwell therein. If the earth were Gold (as one sayth) the grasse Pearles, the trees Siluer, and the fields full of corne and cattell, yet will not God spare any of them for mans sinne. The earth hath comely Closes, fruitefull Fieldes, Vineyards, Zeph. 1. 13. 17. Orchards, Gardens, Cities, Towers, Townes, and stately buildings, God will destroy them, and make them desolate for mans sinne.

Not onely is man punished for sinne, but also the Lande, and other vnreasonable and vnsensible creatures: the Land carrieth the curse of bryers, Gen. 4. 12. Gen. 6. 13. thornes, and thistles, for mans sinne. And as sinne increaseth, so Gods curse vppon the earth, and all that is therein
likewise increaseth.

In Noah his time, for mans sinne, the Land mourned, and all that dwelt therein were cut off (except onely eight persons) with the beastes of the field, foules of the aire, and liuing things on the earth were destroyed, nothing reserued, but what was in the Arke. In Pharao his time, the waters were turned Gen. 7. 4. into blood; the earth was poysoned with Frogges, infected with Flies, the Cattell Exod. 7. 19. 20. Exod. 8. 6. 14. 21. Exod. 9. 3. 19. 21. dyed with murraine, the trees, and hearbs are smitten with haile, their barly and flaxe that should feed and cloath them, were destroyed for their sinnes.

When Saul was commanded to destroy Amaleck, he was charged not only 2. Sam. 15. 3. to kill man, but also sheepe, oxen, and euery liuing thing, man, and beastes, foules, and fishes, trees, and fruites Zeph. 1. 3. Iere. 7. 20. Ioel. 1. 18. of the earth were punished for mans sinne. And heere wee see, when the sinnes of Israel were red ripe, and the bags of their iniquitie sealed vp, then must the poore harmelesse creatures also smart for it.

Sinne maketh God to cut downe all: As an earthly King doth not onely
punish a rebell with death, but also taketh away his Land; so doth God also punish man for sinne, in his commodities. See how odious sinne is before God; Thou seest pestilence, and plagues among men, so as the very stones in many Cities and Townes, where God hath shot his arrowes for sinne, haue seemed to mourne and lament their solitarinesse, beeing growen ouer with grasse, as the plaine field, knowe it is for thy sinne. Thou seest murraines of Cattle, rots of Sheepe, vnseasonable weather, destroying the Corne, and increase of the earth, thy sinnes are the cause of it. Then mayest thou say with Dauid, Its I that haue sinned, 2. Sam. 24. 17. yea I haue done wickedly; but these sheepe what haue they done?

And lastly, whereas the Lord threatneth, that the Land of Iudea should mourne, and all things therein should be destroyed, because there was no mercie, nor truth, nor knowledge of God in the Land: but by swearing, lying, killing, stealing, and whoring, they breake out, and blood touched blood. Let vs looke into our selues, was there euer more want of
mercie among the Iewes, then among vs? Is not charity key-cold, and euen frozen amongst vs? Are not swearing, killing, lying, stealing, and whoring too rife? Are not the holy things of the Lord prophaned among vs? Is not the Lords Supper receiued of many without care of examining themselues, or any conscience of making difference of the Lords body? Is not the blessed word, by some made a cloake to couer their sinnes? And, to lap vp all in a word, are not our sinnes ready to pull downe Gods vengeance vppon our heads?
Let vs then humble our selues by hearty repentance, and breake off the course of sinne betimes, and then God will remooue his iudgements.

Let vs turne from our sinnes, and Zach. 1. 3. Ezek. 18. 3. 32. God in mercy will turne to vs. God would not the death of sinners; yea, he expostulateth with vs, or rather wooes vs to himselfe, Why will ye die, O ye house of Israel?

But except we leaue off sinning, let vs bee sure God will not leaue punishing: If we continue in sinning, Gods
hand will be still stretched out against vs, and as our sinnes increase, so will he send new iudgements vpon vs. Let vs then make an end of sinning, and God will haue done with afflicting.

Sinne is like a surfeit, it must needs be remooued, before any medecine can preuaile. If you amend and redresse your waies, and your workes (saith the Lord) then will I let you dwell in this land; Either Iere. 7. 5. 7. repent, or no fauour with GOD. Wee must acquaint our selues with GOD, be at peace with him, receaue his words, lay them vp in our hearts, and returne to the Almighty, and then the Lord will deale mercifully Iob 22. 21. 22, 23. with vs.

When the weather is vnseasonable, it is a common thing amongst countrey people, to be inquisitiue to know, When changeth the Moone? But rather aske, When changest thou thy heart? The right way to appease Gods wrath, is to cast out the Gibeonites: and if we would haue Gods wrath turned away, we must Iudg. 20. 12, 13. cast out our sinnes. Entertaine the counsell of Daniel, Breake off your sinnes Dan. 4. 24. by righteousnes, and your iniquities by mercie
towards the poore. If we doe this, God will be our Sunne and shield, he will giue vs Psalm. 84. 9. 11. grace, and glory, he will with-hold no good thing from vs, nor suffer euill things to hurt vs, and then the controuersie or quarrell which the Lord hath with vs (for sinne) will be soone ended. Then will the Lord blesse vs, shew vs the light of his countenance, and be mercifull vnto vs; which God for his mercie sake in Christ Iesus graunt.
